creditline: Gift of the Joseph F. McCrindle Collection
description: ink with red wash; women with jugs and baskets at R; male figures with camels at L; seated figure seen from back, LLC; city with buildings and sculptures in background at R
inscription:
Inscriptions, Stamps:

Verso of mount, in black chalk:
[Im Palazzo Vecchio in Florenz sind  / Teppiche mit der Josephsgeschichte / ein Entwurf (d[ie] Traumdeutung)/ ist von Salviati, die übrigen von:      / \"17] (in a circle) / [Gio Barbie] / [HC]

Old mat, inscribed by later hand: [Northern, near Crispijn Van Den Broeck / M. Warshaw]
markings: LLC, stamped in blue: monogram [GV] Lugt 1223; LLC, stamped in brown, smudged: [R] in circle;  stamped in black: [(crown)/CG]
medium: Pen and brown ink, brush and red wash, possibly red chalk, heightened with white
provenance: Commendatore Modesto Ignazio Bonaventura Luigi Genevosio Lugt 545 (five-pearl variant crown; Lugt misidentified as Conte Gelozzi or Gelosi) Turin (until 1794; sold, March 8, to Turinetti); Marchese Giovanni Antonio Turinetti di Priero, Turin (1794-at least 1801). Giuseppe Vallardi, Lugt 1223 (1784-1863), Milan; Anton Rauh, Lugt 2182a (1891-1977), Bamberg; Joseph McCrindle, New York (until d.2008); Joseph F. McCrindle Foundation (2008-2009; gave to MIA)
text: Following the iconoclasm of 1566, in which many of Antwerp’s religious images were destroyed, the thriving market for new works kept Maerten de Vos busy for the rest of the century. A Lutheran until 1583 or 1584, de Vos converted to Catholicism in order to remain in the city. This newly discovered drawing, his earliest by a decade, dates from his Protestant years. It is a design for his Life of Rebecca painting series. The story of Rebecca is told in Genesis. Abraham, wishing his son, Isaac, to marry, sent his servant Eliezer to Mesopotamia to find Isaac a wife. One evening Eliezer waited with his camels by a well. The beautiful Rebecca came to draw water, and when he asked for a drink, she offered water to his camels as well as to him. By this he knew that she was destined to be Isaac’s bride. The drawing shows Rebecca introducing her brother, Laban, to Eliezer.
title: Laban and Rebecca Receiving Eliezer
